name: Slippery Slope
definition: Claiming that one action will inevitably lead to extreme consequences without demonstrating the causal chain.
whyItWorks: Fear is motivating. By painting a vivid worst-case scenario, we make moderate positions seem dangerous. The chain of 'if...then' feels logical even without evidence for each link.

examples.text: If we allow any path to legal status for undocumented immigrants, we're signaling that laws don't matter. Soon there will be no border at all.
examples.analysis: Assumes no stopping points or course corrections are possible. Many countries have paths to legal status without open borders.

examples.text: If we let employers fire people for controversial tweets, soon you'll lose your job for private dinner conversations.
examples.analysis: Plausible-sounding progression, but lacks evidence it's inevitable. Social and legal norms can create stable middle grounds.

examples.text: If we reduce sentences for non-violent drug offenses, criminals will see we're soft and violent crime will explode.
examples.analysis: Assumes direct causal chain without evidence. Many jurisdictions have reduced sentences without increases in violent crime.

examples.text: If the government can regulate one health supplement, they'll eventually ban all natural medicine and force us to use only pharmaceuticals.
examples.analysis: Regulation exists on a spectrum. Requiring evidence for claims is different from banning products.

examples.text: If we keep building high-density housing, we'll destroy every neighborhood's character until cities are just concrete blocks.
examples.analysis: Ignores zoning, design standards, community input, and that some density can coexist with neighborhood character.

promptStarters: If we allow ___, soon we'll have ___, and eventually ___.
This is just the first step toward ___.
Once we start ___, where does it end?
Give them an inch on ___ and they'll take a mile.
